awd_titl_txt: Academic Integrity Management (AIM) of a collaborative three year computer science degree program

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: California State University Monterey Bay Foundation

por.por_cntn:
The project has implemented and documented a cohort-based model with three critical components: (1) an accelerated three-year time frame, (2) collaboration between a community college and a university, and (3) a cohort-based learning model. This one of its kind program has demonstrated substantial improvement of the key metrics of success for first generation, low income and URM students and has been recognized as one of the top tier innovative education programs in California. A publication documenting this model received the best paper recognition at ACM SIGCSE 2018 conference.

The work completed under this project has directly impacted over 160 students who have participated in the program, as well as had a significant impact on the overall quality of the CS programs at Hartnell and Cal State Monterey Bay by strengthening the community college to university pipeline, attracting new industry partners, and building academic and extra-curricular support programming that is available to all students. It was the catalyst for launching a similar 4-year, cohort-based pathway for incoming CS freshmen at Cal State Monterey Bay that has since included over 100 participants, and is being replicated in Southern California with cohorts starting at El Camino College and at California State University Dominguez Hills in fall 2019.

Notable improvements in key metrics evaluated by the program include:

  • A significant increase in the capacity of the CS program at CSUMB. CSUMB is one of the smallest campuses in the 23-campus CSU system that serves almost 500K students.  However, it produced 1/17 of all CSU CS graduates in Spring 2018.

  • A significant demographic shift in CSUMB CS graduates. Prior to launching its CS cohort programs, in Spring 2013, CSUMB produced 1/34 of all Hispanic CS graduates from across the CSU and 1/30 of all female CS graduates. As of Spring 2017, CSUMB produced 1/13 of all Hispanic CS graduates and 1/11 of female CS graduates in the CSU system.

  • 184 students completed CS internships in summer 2015, 2016, 2017, and 2018. Organizations include Adobe, Allstate, Amazon, Apple, Atlassian, BofA, Cisco, Code2040, Driscoll, eBay, Facebook, Google, Intuit, NASA Ames, Nationwide, Salesforce, Uber, VmWare, and Zynga.

  • Improved completion and transfer rates from community college to university. The average 1.5 year Associate degree completion rate and transfer rate for participating students is 83.2% (134 out of 161 cohort students).

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2019
Modified by: Sathya Narayanan

Notable improvements in key metrics evaluated by the program include:


A significant increase in the capacity of the CS program at CSUMB. CSUMB is one of the smallest campuses in the 23-campus CSU system that serves almost 500K students.  However, it produced 1/17 of all CSU CS graduates in Spring 2018.


A significant demographic shift in CSUMB CS graduates. 184 students completed CS internships in summer 2015, 2016, 2017, and 2018. Organizations include Adobe, Allstate, Amazon, Apple, Atlassian, BofA, Cisco, Code2040, Driscoll, eBay, Facebook, Google, Intuit, NASA Ames, Nationwide, Salesforce, Uber, VmWare, and Zynga.
